conclusion: There are four objects (A, B, C, D) on the ground.
A light source is positioned above these objects, casting shadows on the ground.
The shadows (indicated by the red arrows) are cast in front of the objects.
The shadows cast in front of the objects suggest the light source is behind the objects.
The light source moves forward, which means it moves closer to the objects along the direction they are facing.
When the light source moves forward, the shadows will shift to the back of the objects.
The shadows will typically become smaller as the light source moves closer to the objects.
The shadows are now shorter and cast behind the objects.
The observation of shorter shadows cast behind the objects confirms the light source has moved forward.
When the light source moves forward, the shadows cast by objects A, B, C, and D will move to the back and become shorter.
